instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-02016: What is 820-02016? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.BKLT_EN_R: What is BKLT_EN_R? This signal enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKL” before “_EN”. “BKL” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. The “_R” suffix means that the signal is asserted when it is high, as in 3.3v, which is the opposite of the “_L”  suffix.
definitions.BKLT_SCL: What is BKLT_SCL? BKLT_SCL is an I2C signal clock line between the LED driver that creates the LCD backlight power rail that powers the backlight in the screen and the screen. The screen needs to speak to the LED driver on this line before backlight voltage will be created..
definitions.BKLT_SDA: What is BKLT_SDA? BKLT_SDA is a data line between the LCD screen and the LED driver. This data line cannot short to ground. If it does, the screen cannot talk to the LED driver, and the LED driver will not allow the circuit to produce a backlight..
definitions.PPVOUT_LCDBKLT: What is PPVOUT_LCDBKLT? PPVOUT_LCDBKLT is the backlight power rail that is responsible for creating a backlight o nthe screen. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight
threads.message:
Clean board but MacBook hast a dent on a corner, no corrosion.

<SIGNAL>PPVOUT_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> 0.02V

Tried a different screen and same problem

UP800 
<SIGNAL>PP5V_BKLT_A</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP5V_BKLT_A</SIGNAL>  5V
<SIGNAL>BKLT_SCL</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>BKLT_SDA</SIGNAL> 5V
<SIGNAL>BKLT_EN_R</SIGNAL> 0V 
RP850 is OK diode reading is 0.430 but no voltage with screen connected.

All the above was the case at first, now there is no image any longer and of course no backlight.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight
threads.message:
External video present?
Very likely broken solders, or trace...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight
threads.message: Yes sorry I forgot to mention that there is external video, already tried a reflow of the PM with good quality flux, but same thing, should I try the same with the M1 chip?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight
threads.message:
May help in case of broken solder under M1.
However, will not correct broken trace; which can be anywhere on the board.

3V3/<SIGNAL>5V_SW_LCD</SIGNAL> present, at least in the first seconds?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight
threads.message:
I suppose <SIGNAL>LPDP_INT_HGPD</SIGNAL> is also present.
In such case, internal LCD is correctly recognized.
You should have image at least...
